thread.title: Video offers glimpse into relationship slain Lewisville sisters had with father accused of killing them in taxi | Irving | Dallas News
thread.title_full: Video offers glimpse into relationship slain Lewisville sisters had with father accused of killing them in taxi | Irving | Dallas News

title: Video offers glimpse into relationship slain Lewisville sisters had with father accused of killing them in taxi | Irving | Dallas News
text:
Get Unlimited Digital Access Your first month is less than a dollar. $0.99 for first 4 weeks Subscribe Now 
Home video of a father and his teen daughters, who were found dead nine years ago outside an Irving hotel in a cab he had borrowed, hints at what some relatives and friends have said was a physically abusive relationship. 
Sarah Said, 17, and Amina Said, 18, were found shot to death on New Year's Day 2008 in a taxi at an Irving motel. The teens' Egyptian-born father, Yaser Abdel Said, fled and is still at large. 
The footage, obtained by Crime Watch Daily with Chris Hansen and filmed by Yaser Said, shows the girls in their bedroom with Said making comments such as "Sarah sleeps with her pants?" "Mmm, very nice," and "Wow, look at those eyes. I got my eye on you." Amina Said, left, and Sarah Said in their Lewisville ISD school portraits. Lewisville ISD 
In one clip, Amina is playing with a gun. 
"She started telling me just little by little that it was more than him just being protective, it was more him being controlling and abusive," Amina's boyfriend, Joseph Moreno, says. "I wanted to get her away from that so bad, she was such a good person she didn't deserve to live like that." 
The full episode of Crime Watch will air at 4 p.m. Friday on KDAF-TV (Channel 33). 
Amina and Sarah accused their father of sexual abuse in October 1998, when they were 9 and 8 years old. The allegations were reported to the Hill County sheriff's office, and their mother, Patricia Owens, swore in an affidavit that the allegations were true. For years, friends say, slain sisters lived with their father's threats of violence and abuse 
Months later, the girls told authorities that they had lied about the allegations because they did not want to attend schools in a rural community south of Fort Worth, and wanted to live with their grandmother. The charges were dropped. 
Owens' relatives have said Said was prone to violence and that he believed Western society was corrupting his daughters' chastity. This prompted speculation that the slayings were "honor killings," however Owens has rejected that. 
Friends and family members say Said moved the family from Euless to Lewisville to break up his daughter and her non-Muslim boyfriend. The teens attended Lewisville High School where they confided in friends about the physical abuse and their dreams of going to college. Mother of slain teen girls still haunted by alleged honor killings 
A month before the shootings, friends and family said Said became angry because he found one his daughters were dating and threatened to harm them. On Christmas Day, Owens, her daughters and their boyfriends fled the state. 
But they returned to Lewisville on New Year's Eve. Hours later, the daughters were found in the taxi. 
In December 2014, Said made the FBI's Ten Most Wanted List . A $100,000 reward has been offered. The flier says Said always wears dark sunglasses and frequents Denny's and IHOP restaurants. 
Some people believe Said is dead, others believe he could be hiding in plain sight in North Texas, perhaps being sheltered by someone. 
He has ties in Egypt and Canada, and across the country in Texas, New York and Virginia. 
The case has also been featured in a documentary entitled The Price of Honor . View Comments
